PAGE.TITLE: Basic set theory
PAGE.DESCRIPTION:
Set theory is the branch of mathematical logic that studies sets, which informally are
collections of objects. This theory begins by introducing a fundamental binary relation between an
object $o$ and a set $A$. We write that $o \in A$ if the object $o$ is in the set $A$ and
$o \notin A$ if the object $o$ is not in the set $A$. If all the members of the set $B$ are
in $A$ we say that $B$ is a subset of $A$ and write $B \subset A$. Any members of the subset $A$
that are not in $B$ are said to belong to the complement set $B^c$.
Just as arithmatic features binary operators on numbers set theory features binary operations on sets.
If we have two sets $A$ and $B$ two particularly important operations of the sets are the union $A \cup B$
and the intersection $A \cap B$. $A \cup B$ includes all objects that are members of $A$, $B$ or both, while
to be a member of $A \cap B$ an object must be a member of both $A$ and $B$.

UL.LI: You should be able to explain the meaning of the words set, element, subset and complement set.
You should be able construct sets from objects using the symbols $\in$ and $\notin$.

You should be able to explain which elements of a pair of sets belong to the intersection of two sets and which elements belong to the union and you should know how to use the $\cup$ and $\cap$ symbols.
You should be able to use Venn diagrams to illustrate subsets and their complements, set unions and set intersections.

RESOURCE.AUTHOR: J.~F.~McCann
RESOURCE.DESCRIPTION: A brief introduction to elementary set theory.
